channel.title: Discussion about the new IPv6 System
channel.description:
Well, we all know we have billions of people and devices on the net, which means billions of IP's. Currently the standard IP addresses can only hold 255 ^ 4 or 4,228,250,625 (4.3 Billion roughly). The amount of IP addresses is running out, so someone came up with IPv6 for the future. IPv6 uses 8 groups of 4 to distinguish numbers. Like this: 0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000 Now that is a LOT of numbers, let's say the max for each group of four is 9999. 9999 ^ 8 is 9.991003599160125987400839964009E35, or about 999,100,359,916,012,598,740,083,996,400,900,000 or 999.1 DECATILLION!
IMO I think this is way past overkill, what do you think?

item.title: Discussion about the new IPv6 System
item.dc:creator: @Your_Grandpa Your Grandpa
item.description:
@Your_Grandpa wrote:

Read about IPv6 here: http://playground.sun.com/ipv6/INET-IPng-Paper.html
The current ip is in the form 00.00.00.00 (or 000.000.000.000 in decimal) <- each block is 0…FF = 2^8
An IPv6 address is 0000.0000.0000.0000.0000.0000.0000.0000, each block is 0…FFFF = 2^16
Old address 32 bits, new 128 bits.
BTW, IPv6 isn’t exactly new though

Read full topic
item.source: Discussion about the new IPv6 System

item.title: Discussion about the new IPv6 System
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Isn’t the idea of using a home router is to block most malicious atempts because the hacker (wrong word but anyway) will have to know both the routers IP (The way it contacts it) AND the ip of the computer inside the netwok = much harder to hack.

Are you saying through giving us so many IPs we don’t need to do this??? Isn’t it a good idea to force people to do this to prevent others hacking our networks???

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

They already have area codes in them

It’s not overkill but its going to ruin proxying for awhile. Not to mention every IP ban on every site will become void.

item.source: Discussion about the new IPv6 System

item.title: Discussion about the new IPv6 System
item.dc:creator: @philodespotos philodespotos
item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

[quote=“David, post:6, topic:4191”]IPv6 is overkill IMO.

What’s wrong with 000:000:000:000:PORT ?[/quote]
RFC 1883, which, AFAIK, is one of the earliest, if not the earliest, specifications for IPv6, was released in 1995. Today, we do not expect to have IPv6 completely unrolled for at least a couple more years, and probably longer. Meaning, complete time from base specification to full implementation is going to border on 15 years, as a fairly conservative estimate.

They’re overshooting on purpose. They have no idea how rapidly connectivity is going to expand. Reimplementing the protocol which transmits damned-near-everything used on the internet today is not a task anyone wants to have to deal with again any time soon. If IPv6 is still alive and well in 50 years, that’s probably a good thing.

Read full topic
item.source: Discussion about the new IPv6 System

item.title: Discussion about the new IPv6 System
item.dc:creator: @David David
item.description:
@David wrote:

IPv6 is overkill IMO.

What’s wrong with 000:000:000:000:PORT ?

Basically like telephone numbers (!)

Which gives me an idea. AREA CODES FOR IP’s!

Bwahha /genius

Read full topic
